pink primrose.description: A low-growing perennial with cup-shaped pink flowers that often bloom in the evening.
pink primrose.medicinal_uses: Historically used by Native Americans for soothing minor aches and gastrointestinal issues.
pink primrose.habitat: Native to grasslands and open, disturbed sites in North America.

hard-leaved pocket orchid.description: A rare, terrestrial orchid known for its slipper-shaped pink pouch and mottled, hard leaves.
hard-leaved pocket orchid.medicinal_uses: No significant medicinal uses documented; primarily valued for horticulture.
hard-leaved pocket orchid.habitat: Limestone areas and rocky outcrops in Southeast Asia.

canterbury bells.description: A biennial plant producing tall spires of bell-shaped flowers in shades of blue, purple, pink, or white.
canterbury bells.medicinal_uses: Not commonly used in modern medicine; historically symbolic in gardens.
canterbury bells.habitat: Native to southern Europe; cultivated in gardens worldwide.

sweet pea.description: A climbing annual with highly fragrant, butterfly-shaped flowers in a wide color range.
sweet pea.medicinal_uses: Seeds are toxic if ingested; plant is not used medicinally.
sweet pea.habitat: Native to Sicily, southern Italy, and the Aegean Islands; grown in temperate gardens.

english marigold.description: A cheerful annual with bright orange or yellow, daisy-like flower heads.
english marigold.medicinal_uses: Flower petals are used in salves, teas, and tinctures for skin inflammation, wounds, and as an antiseptic.
english marigold.habitat: Native to southern Europe; widely naturalized in gardens and temperate regions.

tiger lily.description: A vigorous perennial with striking orange flowers covered in dark spots and recurved petals.
tiger lily.medicinal_uses: Bulbs are edible and used in some traditional Asian medicines for respiratory and heart conditions.
tiger lily.habitat: Native to China, Japan, and Korea; found in meadows, forest edges, and gardens.

moon orchid.description: An epiphytic orchid with elegant, arching sprays of white flowers that resemble moths in flight.
moon orchid.medicinal_uses: Not used medicinally; one of the most popular ornamental orchids worldwide.
moon orchid.habitat: Tropical rainforests of Southeast Asia and Australia, growing on trees.
moon orchid.blooming_season: Can bloom multiple times a year, often in Spring or Fall

bird of paradise.description: A tropical perennial with unique, crane-like orange and blue flowers emerging from a beak-shaped bract.
bird of paradise.medicinal_uses: No significant medicinal uses; important as a cut flower and ornamental.
bird of paradise.habitat: Native to South Africa; cultivated in tropical and subtropical gardens.

monkshood.description: A tall perennial with hooded, deep purple-blue flowers and deeply divided, dark green leaves.
monkshood.medicinal_uses: Historically used as a pain reliever and sedative, but all parts are highly poisonous. Use is dangerous and not recommended.
monkshood.habitat: Native to western and central Europe; found in moist pastures and mountain meadows.

globe thistle.description: A striking perennial with spherical, steely-blue flower heads atop silvery, spiny stems.
globe thistle.medicinal_uses: Root extracts have been used in traditional medicine for headaches and as a diuretic.
globe thistle.habitat: Native to Europe and Asia; thrives in dry, sunny meadows and rocky slopes.

snapdragon.description: A popular annual or perennial with colorful, tubular flowers that 'snap' open when squeezed.
snapdragon.medicinal_uses: Historically used as a poultice for tumors and ulcers; now primarily an ornamental.
snapdragon.habitat: Native to the Mediterranean region; widely grown in temperate gardens.

colt's foot.description: A low-growing perennial with yellow, dandelion-like flowers that appear before the heart-shaped leaves.
colt's foot.medicinal_uses: Flowers and leaves have been used in syrups and teas to soothe coughs, bronchitis, and sore throats.
colt's foot.habitat: Native to Europe and parts of Asia; colonizes disturbed, clay-rich soils, roadsides, and riverbanks.

king protea.description: A large shrub with massive, iconic flower heads consisting of a central dome surrounded by colorful bracts.
king protea.medicinal_uses: No major medicinal uses; it is the national flower of South Africa and prized in floristry.
king protea.habitat: Endemic to the fynbos region of South Africa, on well-drained, acidic, rocky slopes.

spear thistle.description: A tall, spiny biennial with purple, fluffy flower heads and fiercely lobed, prickly leaves.
spear thistle.medicinal_uses: Root has been used as a tonic and astringent; young stems are edible when peeled.
spear thistle.habitat: Native to Europe and Asia; an invasive weed in pastures, roadsides, and disturbed ground.

yellow iris.description: A robust, rhizomatous perennial with bright yellow flowers and sword-shaped leaves.
yellow iris.medicinal_uses: Rhizome has been used as a cathartic and emetic, but it is toxic and can cause severe discomfort.
yellow iris.habitat: Native to Europe, western Asia, and northwest Africa; grows in wetlands, pond edges, and riverbanks.

globe-flower.description: A herbaceous perennial with spherical, bright yellow or orange buttercup-like flowers.
globe-flower.medicinal_uses: Historically used in folk medicine for wounds and as a remedy for scurvy, but it contains irritant compounds.
globe-flower.habitat: Native to damp meadows, stream banks, and alpine regions of Europe and Asia.

purple coneflower.description: A hardy perennial with large, daisy-like purple flowers featuring a prominent spiky, coppery-orange central cone.
purple coneflower.medicinal_uses: Widely used to support immune function and reduce the severity and duration of colds and flu.
purple coneflower.habitat: Native to prairies, open woodlands, and roadsides in central and eastern North America.

peruvian lily.description: A tuberous perennial with clusters of lily-like flowers in vibrant colors like orange, yellow, pink, and white, often with speckled throats.
peruvian lily.medicinal_uses: No significant medicinal uses; primarily a popular and long-lasting cut flower.
peruvian lily.habitat: Native to grasslands and mountain slopes in South America; widely cultivated in gardens.

balloon flower.description: A clump-forming perennial named for its unique flower buds that swell like balloons before opening into star-shaped blue, purple, or white flowers.
balloon flower.medicinal_uses: The root (Platycodon root) is used in traditional Korean and Chinese medicine to treat respiratory ailments like coughs and sore throats.
balloon flower.habitat: Native to East Asia; grows in sunny meadows, slopes, and woodland edges.

giant white arum lily.description: A striking perennial with large, pure white, funnel-shaped spathes surrounding a yellow spadix and broad, glossy green leaves.
giant white arum lily.medicinal_uses: Used in traditional medicine for dressing wounds and treating headaches, but all parts are toxic if ingested raw.
giant white arum lily.habitat: Native to southern Africa in marshes and stream banks; naturalized in similar habitats worldwide.

fire lily.description: A tall lily bearing upward-facing, vibrant orange flowers with dark spots. Some varieties produce bulbils in the leaf axils.
fire lily.medicinal_uses: Bulbs have been used in poultices for ulcers and skin inflammations in traditional European medicine.
fire lily.habitat: Native to mountainous regions of Europe, thriving in meadows, scrub, and rocky slopes.

pincushion flower.description: A perennial or annual with intricate, domed flower heads in shades of blue, lavender, pink, or white, resembling a pincushion filled with pins.
pincushion flower.medicinal_uses: Historically, the genus name 'Scabiosa' derives from its use in treating scabies and other itchy skin conditions.
pincushion flower.habitat: Native to Europe, Asia, and Africa; found in meadows, grasslands, and cultivated gardens.

fritillary.description: A bulbous perennial with distinctive, nodding, bell-shaped flowers in a chequered pattern of purple and white.
fritillary.medicinal_uses: Historically used in cough medicines, but many species are now rare and protected.
fritillary.habitat: Native to European floodplain meadows and damp grasslands.

red ginger.description: A tropical plant with striking, long-lasting bright red bracts that form a cone-shaped inflorescence, from which small white flowers emerge.
red ginger.medicinal_uses: Primarily ornamental; related species in the ginger family have widespread medicinal uses.
red ginger.habitat: Native to Southeast Asia and the Pacific Islands; thrives in humid tropical forests and gardens.
red ginger.blooming_season: Year-round in tropical climates, peaking in Summer

grape hyacinth.description: A small, bulbous spring plant producing dense spikes of tiny, urn-shaped, deep blue flowers that resemble clusters of grapes.
grape hyacinth.medicinal_uses: No major medicinal uses; occasionally used in perfumery.
grape hyacinth.habitat: Native to the Mediterranean region; naturalized in lawns, woodlands, and rocky areas.

corn poppy.description: An annual wildflower with delicate, bright red petals surrounding a dark center, often found fluttering in fields.
corn poppy.medicinal_uses: Mild sedative properties; petals are used in syrups and teas for coughs, insomnia, and mild pain relief.
corn poppy.habitat: Native to Europe and Asia; common in cultivated fields, roadsides, and disturbed soil.

prince of wales feathers.description: An annual plant with tall, upright, plume-like inflorescences of deep red or purple flowers and broad green leaves.
prince of wales feathers.medicinal_uses: Leaves are nutritious and have been used as a poultice for wounds; seeds are a gluten-free grain.
prince of wales feathers.habitat: Native to the Americas; cultivated as a grain and ornamental, also found in disturbed areas.

stemless gentian.description: A low-growing, mat-forming perennial with large, solitary, trumpet-shaped, intense blue flowers that sit directly on the basal leaves.
stemless gentian.medicinal_uses: The root is a classic bitter tonic used to stimulate digestion and appetite.
stemless gentian.habitat: Native to the alpine meadows and mountains of central and southern Europe.

artichoke.description: A thistle-like perennial grown for its large, edible flower buds composed of fleshy bracts and a tender heart.
artichoke.medicinal_uses: Leaf extracts are used to support liver function, lower cholesterol, and aid digestion.
artichoke.habitat: Native to the Mediterranean region; cultivated in temperate climates worldwide.

sweet william.description: A short-lived perennial forming dense clusters of small, fragrant flowers with serrated petals in red, pink, white, or bicolor patterns.
sweet william.medicinal_uses: Not commonly used medicinally; historically used in tonics for its mild antiseptic properties.
sweet william.habitat: Native to southern Europe and parts of Asia; naturalized in meadows and gardens in temperate zones.

carnation.description: A popular perennial with fragrant, ruffled flowers in a wide range of colors including pink, red, white, and yellow.
carnation.medicinal_uses: Traditionally used in herbal teas for calming nerves, reducing inflammation, and treating minor skin conditions.
carnation.habitat: Native to the Mediterranean region; widely cultivated in gardens and greenhouses worldwide.

garden phlox.description: A tall perennial with large clusters of fragrant, five-petaled flowers in shades of pink, purple, white, and red.
garden phlox.medicinal_uses: Historically used by Native Americans to treat skin conditions and as a mild laxative.
garden phlox.habitat: Native to eastern North America; thrives in meadows, open woodlands, and garden borders.

love in the mist.description: An annual plant with feathery, fine-cut leaves and delicate blue, white, or pink flowers surrounded by a misty bract of fine leaves.
love in the mist.medicinal_uses: Seeds have been used as a digestive aid and to treat intestinal worms; also used as a culinary spice.
love in the mist.habitat: Native to southern Europe and North Africa; grows in fields, roadsides, and gardens.

mexican aster.description: A tall annual with daisy-like flowers in pink, white, or crimson colors, with feathery, fern-like foliage.
mexican aster.medicinal_uses: Limited medicinal use; primarily ornamental, though some species are used in traditional medicine for skin conditions.
mexican aster.habitat: Native to Mexico and the southern United States; thrives in open, sunny areas with well-drained soil.

alpine sea holly.description: A striking perennial with metallic blue, thistle-like flower heads surrounded by spiny, ruffled bracts.
alpine sea holly.medicinal_uses: Root has been used as a diuretic and to treat urinary tract infections in traditional medicine.
alpine sea holly.habitat: Native to alpine meadows and rocky slopes in central and southern Europe.

ruby-lipped cattleya.description: A showy epiphytic orchid with large, fragrant flowers featuring a distinctive ruby-red lip and lavender petals.
ruby-lipped cattleya.medicinal_uses: No significant medicinal uses; highly valued as an ornamental and parent of many hybrid orchids.
ruby-lipped cattleya.habitat: Native to rainforests of Brazil, growing on trees in humid environments.

cape flower.description: A diverse genus of shrubs known for their dramatic, large flower heads with stiff, colorful bracts.
cape flower.medicinal_uses: Limited medicinal use; primarily valued for cut flowers and ornamental gardening.
cape flower.habitat: Native to South Africa's fynbos region, particularly the Cape Floristic Region.
cape flower.blooming_season: Varies by species, generally Spring to Summer

great masterwort.description: A clump-forming perennial with unique, pincushion-like flower heads surrounded by papery bracts in white, pink, or red shades.
great masterwort.medicinal_uses: Historically used to treat wounds and digestive disorders; roots were considered a remedy for snake bites.
great masterwort.habitat: Native to mountain meadows and damp woodlands in central and eastern Europe.

siam tulip.description: Not a true tulip, but a tropical perennial with cone-shaped pink or purple bracts that resemble flowers, rising above lance-shaped leaves.
siam tulip.medicinal_uses: Related to turmeric but not widely used medicinally; primarily grown as an ornamental cut flower.
siam tulip.habitat: Native to Thailand and Cambodia; grows in tropical forests and cultivated gardens.

lenten rose.description: An evergreen perennial with nodding, cup-shaped flowers in shades of white, pink, purple, or green that bloom early in the year.
lenten rose.medicinal_uses: Historically used as a purgative and to treat worms, but all parts are toxic and can be dangerous.
lenten rose.habitat: Native to Greece and Turkey; thrives in woodland gardens and shaded, moist areas.

barbeton daisy.description: A popular perennial daisy with large, colorful flower heads in bright shades of red, orange, yellow, pink, and white.
barbeton daisy.medicinal_uses: No significant medicinal uses; one of the most important cut flowers in the floral industry.
barbeton daisy.habitat: Native to South Africa; cultivated worldwide in gardens and greenhouses.
barbeton daisy.blooming_season: Spring through Fall in suitable climates

daffodil.description: A spring-blooming bulb with trumpet-shaped flowers, typically yellow or white, surrounded by six petals.
daffodil.medicinal_uses: Contains alkaloids with potential medicinal properties, but is toxic if ingested; used historically for wound healing.
daffodil.habitat: Native to Europe and North Africa; naturalized in meadows, woodlands, and gardens worldwide.

sword lily.description: A tall perennial with sword-shaped leaves and showy flower spikes in a wide range of colors, often arranged on one side of the stem.
sword lily.medicinal_uses: Corms have been used to treat diarrhea and dysentery; also used in poultices for wounds.
sword lily.habitat: Native to South Africa, Mediterranean Europe, and Asia; grows in well-drained soils in sunny locations.

poinsettia.description: A shrub known for its bright red, pink, or white bracts (modified leaves) that surround small, yellow flowers.
poinsettia.medicinal_uses: Latex has been used in traditional medicine to treat fevers and skin conditions, but can be irritating.
poinsettia.habitat: Native to Mexico and Central America; widely cultivated as a holiday ornamental plant.

bolero deep blue.description: A cultivar of cornflower with intense, deep blue, double flowers on slender stems with gray-green foliage.
bolero deep blue.medicinal_uses: Flowers have anti-inflammatory properties and are used in eye washes and skin tonics.
bolero deep blue.habitat: Cultivated variety; original species native to European grain fields and disturbed ground.

wallflower.description: A perennial or biennial plant with clusters of fragrant, four-petaled flowers in shades of yellow, orange, red, or purple.
wallflower.medicinal_uses: Historically used in traditional medicine for heart conditions and as a diuretic, but can be toxic in large doses.
wallflower.habitat: Native to southern Europe; commonly found on old walls, cliffs, and rocky places.

marigold.description: An annual plant with bright orange, yellow, or red pom-pom like flowers and finely divided, aromatic foliage.
marigold.medicinal_uses: Used in traditional medicine for skin wounds, inflammation, and as an antiseptic; also planted as a natural pest deterrent.
marigold.habitat: Native to the Americas; widely cultivated in gardens worldwide in sunny locations.

buttercup.description: A common perennial with glossy, bright yellow flowers that have a distinctive cup shape and shiny petals.
buttercup.medicinal_uses: Generally considered toxic; historically used externally in poultices for arthritis and nerve pain with caution.
buttercup.habitat: Found worldwide in meadows, pastures, woodlands, and damp areas.

oxeye daisy.description: A perennial wildflower with white, daisy-like petals surrounding a bright yellow central disc.
oxeye daisy.medicinal_uses: Traditionally used to treat coughs, wounds, and skin conditions; flowers and leaves are edible in moderation.
oxeye daisy.habitat: Native to Europe and Asia; naturalized in fields, roadsides, and grasslands worldwide.

common dandelion.description: A perennial herb with bright yellow composite flowers that turn into spherical seed heads (clocks).
common dandelion.medicinal_uses: Leaves are diuretic and rich in vitamins; roots support liver health and digestion; used as a detoxifying herb.
common dandelion.habitat: Ubiquitous in lawns, meadows, roadsides, and disturbed soils across temperate regions.
common dandelion.blooming_season: Spring to Fall, nearly year-round in mild climates

petunia.description: A popular annual with trumpet-shaped flowers in nearly every color, often with contrasting veins or edges.
petunia.medicinal_uses: No significant medicinal uses; primarily ornamental, though some species have mild antimicrobial properties.
petunia.habitat: Cultivated hybrid; native species from South America; grown in gardens, containers, and hanging baskets.

wild pansy.description: A small annual or short-lived perennial with cheerful three-colored flowers typically in purple, yellow, and white.
wild pansy.medicinal_uses: Used in traditional European medicine for skin conditions (eczema, acne), respiratory issues, and as a mild diuretic.
wild pansy.habitat: Native to Europe and Asia; grows in fields, meadows, and open woodlands.

primula.description: A low-growing perennial forming a rosette of wrinkled leaves, with clusters of pale yellow, fragrant flowers.
primula.medicinal_uses: Flowers have been used for nervous tension and insomnia; roots as an expectorant for coughs.
primula.habitat: Native to western and southern Europe; found in woodlands, hedgerows, and shaded banks.

sunflower.description: A tall annual with a large, dark central disc surrounded by bright yellow ray florets; heads track the sun.
sunflower.medicinal_uses: Seeds are nutritious and rich in vitamin E; oil is used for skin conditions; historically used for pulmonary ailments.
sunflower.habitat: Native to North America; cultivated worldwide in sunny, open fields.

pelargonium.description: Commonly called geraniums, these plants have rounded, often scented leaves and clusters of five-petaled flowers.
pelargonium.medicinal_uses: Essential oils (especially from rose-scented varieties) used in aromatherapy for stress relief and skin care.
pelargonium.habitat: Native to South Africa; widely cultivated as bedding plants and in containers in temperate regions.

bishop of llandaff.description: A cultivar of dahlia with stunning, semi-double scarlet red flowers contrasted by dark, almost black, foliage.
bishop of llandaff.medicinal_uses: No specific medicinal uses; valued as an ornamental garden plant.
bishop of llandaff.habitat: Cultivated variety; requires well-drained soil and full sun in garden settings.

gaura.description: A perennial with delicate, wand-like stems covered in small white or pink flowers that resemble fluttering butterflies.
gaura.medicinal_uses: Not widely used medicinally; primarily an ornamental plant for naturalistic gardens.
gaura.habitat: Native to southern North America; thrives in prairies, open woodlands, and well-drained garden beds.

geranium.description: A hardy perennial (true geranium) with palmately lobed leaves and saucer-shaped flowers in blue, purple, pink, or white.
geranium.medicinal_uses: Root and herb used as an astringent, for diarrhea, and to stanch bleeding; also for mouth ulcers and sore throats.
geranium.habitat: Native to temperate regions worldwide; found in woodlands, meadows, and alpine areas.

orange dahlia.description: A tuberous perennial producing large, vibrant orange flower heads that can range from single to fully double forms.
orange dahlia.medicinal_uses: Historically, tubers were consumed for their inulin content to support blood sugar and digestion.
orange dahlia.habitat: Cultivated variety; native to Mexico and Central America; requires full sun and rich, well-drained soil.

pink-yellow dahlia.description: A dahlia cultivar featuring stunning bicolor blooms with petals that blend or contrast pink and yellow hues.
pink-yellow dahlia.medicinal_uses: Similar to other dahlias, tubers contain inulin and have been used for dietary support.
pink-yellow dahlia.habitat: Cultivated garden plant; thrives in sunny locations with fertile, moist but well-drained soil.

cautleya spicata.description: A rhizomatous perennial with striking spikes of tubular yellow-orange flowers and attractive, bamboo-like foliage.
cautleya spicata.medicinal_uses: Not widely documented for medicinal use; primarily valued as an ornamental plant in shade gardens.
cautleya spicata.habitat: Native to the Himalayas and China; grows in forest understories and moist, shaded mountain slopes.

japanese anemone.description: A graceful perennial with tall, wiry stems bearing simple, saucer-shaped flowers in shades of pink or white with a central golden boss.
japanese anemone.medicinal_uses: Used in traditional Chinese medicine for treating headaches, dizziness, and skin conditions.
japanese anemone.habitat: Native to China (despite common name); naturalized in Japan and temperate gardens worldwide; prefers partial shade.

black-eyed susan.description: A cheerful, drought-tolerant perennial with bright yellow or orange ray florets surrounding a distinctive dark brown to black central cone.
black-eyed susan.medicinal_uses: Root tea used by Native Americans to treat colds, flu, and as a general immune stimulant; also for wound washing.
black-eyed susan.habitat: Native to North American prairies, meadows, roadsides, and open woodlands.

silverbush.description: A compact, evergreen shrub with silvery, silky foliage and morning-glory-like white flowers with yellow centers.
silverbush.medicinal_uses: No significant medicinal uses; grown primarily for its ornamental foliage and flowers in dry gardens.
silverbush.habitat: Native to coastal and rocky areas of the Mediterranean region.

californian poppy.description: The state flower of California, known for its vibrant orange (sometimes yellow or red), cup-shaped flowers and delicate, blue-green fern-like foliage.
californian poppy.medicinal_uses: Used as a mild sedative and analgesic for anxiety, insomnia, and pain relief; non-addictive alternative to opium poppy.
californian poppy.habitat: Native to California and the southwestern United States; thrives in open, sunny areas with well-drained soil.

osteospermum.description: Also called African daisy, a perennial or annual with daisy-like flowers in vibrant purples, pinks, whites, and yellows, often with a contrasting central disc.
osteospermum.medicinal_uses: Primarily ornamental; no well-documented medicinal uses.
osteospermum.habitat: Native to South Africa; cultivated in gardens and containers in sunny locations worldwide.

spring crocus.description: A small, early-blooming cormous plant with goblet-shaped flowers in purple, white, yellow, or striped patterns, often appearing through snow.
spring crocus.medicinal_uses: Not to be confused with saffron crocus; primarily ornamental, though some species have been used in traditional cough remedies.
spring crocus.habitat: Native to alpine meadows and woodlands in Europe; naturalized in lawns and gardens.

bearded iris.description: A perennial rhizome with striking, ornate flowers featuring three upright standards and three drooping falls adorned with a fuzzy 'beard'.
bearded iris.medicinal_uses: Rhizome (orris root) used in traditional medicine as a decongestant, diuretic, and in perfumery as a fixative.
bearded iris.habitat: Cultivated hybrid of European origin; prefers sunny, well-drained garden beds.

windflower.description: A low-growing, tuberous perennial with daisy-like flowers in blue, white, or pink, and fern-like foliage.
windflower.medicinal_uses: Contains irritant compounds; not recommended for internal use. Historically used externally for gout and rheumatism with caution.
windflower.habitat: Native to southeastern Europe and the Caucasus; grows in woodlands, scrub, and rocky slopes.

tree poppy.description: A tall, woody-based perennial or subshrub with large, fragrant, crinkled white flowers and a central boss of golden stamens.
tree poppy.medicinal_uses: Used by indigenous peoples as a sedative and pain reliever; however, all parts are potentially toxic.
tree poppy.habitat: Native to dry chaparral and coastal sage scrub in southern California and northern Mexico.

gazania.description: A low-growing, drought-tolerant perennial with vibrant daisy-like flowers in hot colors (orange, yellow, red) that close at night or on cloudy days.
gazania.medicinal_uses: Primarily ornamental; no significant traditional medicinal uses documented.
gazania.habitat: Native to South Africa; thrives in coastal, sandy soils and sunny rockeries.

azalea.description: A popular spring-flowering shrub with clusters of brightly colored, often funnel-shaped flowers in shades of pink, red, white, or purple.
azalea.medicinal_uses: Many species contain grayanotoxins and are toxic; not used internally. Some traditional uses for skin conditions with extreme caution.
azalea.habitat: Native to Asia, Europe, and North America; prefers acidic, well-drained soil in partial shade.

water lily.description: An aquatic plant with floating, round leaves and elegant, fragrant flowers that bloom on or above the water's surface.
water lily.medicinal_uses: Used in traditional medicine across cultures for diarrhea, heart conditions, and as an anti-inflammatory; rhizomes and flowers are edible.
water lily.habitat: Found in still or slow-moving freshwater ponds, lakes, and marshes worldwide.

rose.description: A woody perennial with thorny stems, pinnate leaves, and iconic, often fragrant flowers with numerous petals.
rose.medicinal_uses: Rose hips are rich in vitamin C and used for immune support; petals used in aromatherapy for stress relief and in skin care.
rose.habitat: Native to various temperate regions of the Northern Hemisphere; cultivated globally in gardens.
rose.blooming_season: Spring to Fall (varies by species and cultivar)

thorn apple.description: An annual plant with large, trumpet-shaped white or purple flowers and spiny seed pods. Also known as Jimsonweed.
thorn apple.medicinal_uses: Contains potent tropane alkaloids; historically used as a pain reliever and asthma treatment but is extremely toxic and dangerous.
thorn apple.habitat: Native to North America; now a widespread weed in disturbed soils, roadsides, and fields.

morning glory.description: A fast-growing annual vine with heart-shaped leaves and trumpet-shaped flowers that open in the morning and close by afternoon.
morning glory.medicinal_uses: Seeds of some species contain LSA (similar to LSD) and have been used in traditional rituals; also used as a laxative in some cultures.
morning glory.habitat: Native to tropical Americas; now widespread in gardens, fields, and disturbed areas worldwide.

passion flower.description: A vigorous vine with intricate, showy flowers featuring a crown of filaments, and three-lobed leaves.
passion flower.medicinal_uses: Widely used as a sedative and anxiolytic for anxiety, insomnia, and nervous disorders.
passion flower.habitat: Native to southeastern United States and Central/South America; grows in sunny fields, roadsides, and thickets.

lotus.description: An aquatic perennial with large, round leaves that float or rise above water, and majestic pink or white flowers with a distinctive seed pod.
lotus.medicinal_uses: All parts are used in traditional medicine: seeds for digestion, leaves for fever, rhizomes as a food and tonic.
lotus.habitat: Native to Asia and Australia; grows in shallow, still freshwater ponds and lakes.

toad lily.description: A shade-loving perennial with orchid-like flowers speckled with purple spots, growing along arching stems.
toad lily.medicinal_uses: Limited medicinal use; primarily ornamental, though some species used in traditional Asian medicine for burns.
toad lily.habitat: Native to Japan; thrives in moist, shaded woodland gardens and forest floors.

anthurium.description: A tropical plant with glossy, heart-shaped red, pink, or white spathes surrounding a yellow spadix, and dark green leaves.
anthurium.medicinal_uses: No significant medicinal uses; popular as a long-lasting cut flower and houseplant.
anthurium.habitat: Native to rainforests of Colombia and Ecuador; grown as a greenhouse or indoor plant.

frangipani.description: A tropical tree or shrub with thick, succulent branches, fragrant five-petaled flowers in white, yellow, pink, or red.
frangipani.medicinal_uses: Latex used externally for skin conditions; bark and flowers used in traditional medicine for fever and inflammation (toxic if ingested).
frangipani.habitat: Native to Central America and the Caribbean; cultivated in tropical and subtropical gardens worldwide.
frangipani.blooming_season: Spring to Fall in warm climates

clematis.description: A climbing vine with woody stems, compound leaves, and large, showy flowers in various colors and forms.
clematis.medicinal_uses: Some species used in traditional Chinese medicine for pain, arthritis, and urinary issues (contains irritants, use with caution).
clematis.habitat: Native to temperate regions worldwide; grows in woodlands, hedgerows, and cultivated gardens.

hibiscus.description: A tropical shrub with large, trumpet-shaped flowers in vibrant red, pink, orange, yellow, or white.
hibiscus.medicinal_uses: Flower tea (especially Hibiscus sabdariffa) used to lower blood pressure, cholesterol, and as a rich source of antioxidants.
hibiscus.habitat: Native to East Asia; widely cultivated in tropical and subtropical regions.

columbine.description: A perennial with delicate, nodding flowers with backward-pointing spurs, in shades of blue, purple, pink, white, or yellow.
columbine.medicinal_uses: Historically used for sore throats and skin conditions; seeds are toxic and should not be ingested.
columbine.habitat: Native to Europe; grows in woodlands, meadows, and rocky slopes.

desert-rose.description: A succulent shrub with a thick, swollen caudex, glossy leaves, and trumpet-shaped flowers in pink, red, or white.
desert-rose.medicinal_uses: Latex used traditionally as arrow poison and for skin conditions; highly toxic if ingested.
desert-rose.habitat: Native to arid regions of Africa and the Arabian Peninsula; grown as an ornamental in dry, sunny climates.

tree mallow.description: A biennial or short-lived perennial shrub with large, hairy leaves and pink or purple hollyhock-like flowers.
tree mallow.medicinal_uses: Leaves and flowers used in poultices for wounds and bruises; also as a mild digestive tea.
tree mallow.habitat: Native to coastal regions of Europe and the Mediterranean; grows on cliffs, dunes, and waste ground.

magnolia.description: An evergreen tree with large, glossy leaves and huge, fragrant white flowers that can be up to 12 inches across.
magnolia.medicinal_uses: Bark used in traditional Chinese medicine for anxiety, asthma, and digestive issues.
magnolia.habitat: Native to southeastern United States; cultivated in temperate gardens worldwide.

cyclamen.description: A tuberous perennial with heart-shaped leaves often marbled with silver, and distinctive reflexed petals in white, pink, or red.
cyclamen.medicinal_uses: Tuber used historically for skin conditions and as a purgative, but is toxic and can be dangerous.
cyclamen.habitat: Native to the Mediterranean and Middle East; grows in woodland and rocky areas; popular pot plant.

watercress.description: A fast-growing aquatic or semi-aquatic perennial with small, white flowers and peppery-tasting leaves.
watercress.medicinal_uses: Rich in vitamins and minerals; traditionally used as a blood purifier, digestive aid, and for respiratory health.
watercress.habitat: Native to Europe and Asia; grows in clean, slow-moving streams and springs.

canna lily.description: A tropical perennial with large, banana-like leaves and bright flowers in red, orange, yellow, or pink.
canna lily.medicinal_uses: Rhizomes used in traditional medicine for fever, diarrhea, and as a diuretic; seeds used as beads.
canna lily.habitat: Native to tropical Americas; cultivated in wetlands, gardens, and as pond margin plants.

hippeastrum.description: Often called amaryllis, a bulbous plant with large, trumpet-shaped flowers on a tall, leafless stalk, in red, white, pink, or striped.
hippeastrum.medicinal_uses: Bulbs contain toxic alkaloids; used with extreme caution in traditional medicine for wounds and as an emetic.
hippeastrum.habitat: Native to tropical South America; widely grown as a potted plant and in gardens in warm climates.

bee balm.description: A clump-forming perennial with shaggy, tubular flowers in red, pink, or purple, and aromatic leaves.
bee balm.medicinal_uses: Leaves used to make Oswego tea; antiseptic properties for sore throats, colds, and as a digestive aid.
bee balm.habitat: Native to eastern North America; grows in moist prairies, woods, and stream banks.

ball moss.description: An epiphytic bromeliad forming small, gray-green, spherical clumps that attach to trees, wires, or rocks.
ball moss.medicinal_uses: Used in traditional medicine for diarrhea, hemorrhages, and as a poultice for wounds.
ball moss.habitat: Native to the Americas; grows on tree branches, telephone wires, and rocks in warm, humid climates.

foxglove.description: A biennial with tall spikes of tubular, spotted flowers in purple, pink, white, or yellow, and a basal rosette of hairy leaves.
foxglove.medicinal_uses: Source of digitalis, a cardiac glycoside used to treat heart failure and arrhythmias (highly toxic if self-administered).
foxglove.habitat: Native to Europe; naturalized in woodlands, clearings, and gardens in temperate regions.

bougainvillea.description: A thorny, woody vine known for its vibrant papery bracts in magenta, purple, orange, or white surrounding small white flowers.
bougainvillea.medicinal_uses: Flowers and bracts used in traditional medicine for cough, fever, and as an anti-inflammatory.
bougainvillea.habitat: Native to South America; cultivated in tropical and subtropical gardens, often as a hedge or climbing plant.
bougainvillea.blooming_season: Year-round in warm climates, best in dry seasons

camellia.description: An evergreen shrub with glossy, dark green leaves and formal, rose-like flowers in white, pink, or red.
camellia.medicinal_uses: Seeds produce tea oil used in cooking and cosmetics; leaves of C. sinensis used for tea (antioxidant properties).
camellia.habitat: Native to East Asia; grows in woodland gardens and acidic, well-drained soils.

mallow.description: A biennial or perennial with lobed leaves and pink or purple veined flowers with a distinctive column of fused stamens.
mallow.medicinal_uses: Leaves and flowers used as a soothing demulcent for coughs, sore throats, and skin irritations.
mallow.habitat: Native to Europe, North Africa, and Asia; grows in fields, roadsides, and waste places.

mexican petunia.description: A herbaceous perennial with lance-shaped leaves and trumpet-shaped purple, pink, or white flowers.
mexican petunia.medicinal_uses: Used in traditional Mexican medicine for fever, inflammation, and as a diuretic; also for snake bites.
mexican petunia.habitat: Native to Mexico, the Caribbean, and South America; invasive in wetlands and disturbed areas in warm climates.

bromelia.description: A diverse genus of tropical plants, often epiphytic, with rosettes of stiff, spiny leaves and colorful flower spikes.
bromelia.medicinal_uses: Some species have edible fruits; sap used traditionally for skin conditions and as an anti-inflammatory.
bromelia.habitat: Native to tropical Americas; grows in rainforests, on trees, rocks, or as terrestrial plants.
bromelia.blooming_season: Varies by species, often Spring to Summer

blanket flower.description: A drought-tolerant annual or perennial with daisy-like flowers in vibrant red and yellow patterns, resembling woven blankets.
blanket flower.medicinal_uses: Root tea used by Native Americans for gastroenteritis and skin disorders; also as a general tonic.
blanket flower.habitat: Native to North and South America; thrives in prairies, plains, and dry, sunny gardens.

trumpet creeper.description: A vigorous, woody vine with compound leaves and clusters of large, trumpet-shaped orange or red flowers attractive to hummingbirds.
trumpet creeper.medicinal_uses: Used in traditional medicine as a diuretic and for skin infections; can cause dermatitis in some people.
trumpet creeper.habitat: Native to eastern United States; grows in woodlands, along streams, and on fences.

blackberry lily.description: A perennial with iris-like leaves and spotted orange flowers that give way to clusters of blackberry-like seed pods.
blackberry lily.medicinal_uses: Rhizome used in traditional Chinese medicine for sore throat, cough, asthma, and mumps.
blackberry lily.habitat: Native to East Asia; grows in well-drained soils in sunny meadows and garden borders.
